item.title: Metro Awakening: All Weapons, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Metro Awakening brings interactivity with weapons like manually ejecting magazines, offering a practical and immersive VR experience.
  • The game features a variety of weapons such as the Tokarev pistol, Helsing crossbow, and improvised grenades for tactical versatility.
  • Metro Awakening offers a mix of powerful weapons like the Kalash rifle and the mounted DShK machine gun, enhancing combat experiences.

Metro Awakening is the latest entry into the highly acclaimed Metro series, based upon the novels of the same name by Dmitry Glukhovsky. Though technically the fourth entry into the video game series, Metro Awakening is the first to take place in VR and contains its own standalone story separate from the events following Artyom in the main games and books. Though the story of Metro Awakening is a linear experience, players will still get the chance to try out plenty of different weapons throughout.

Metro Awakening introduces lots of interactivity with its weapons, including the ability to manually eject magazines and check the chamber for loaded rounds - both of which not only feel awesome to do in VR, but have a very practical use as well. However, not every weapon is suitable for every situation, and so we'll be ranking every weapon in Metro Awakening to see how they stack up.

7 Tokarev

A Fast And Accurate Pistol Ideal As A Sidearm

The Tokarev is a relatively basic pistol, and will certainly come in handy at various points of the game's story. Along with being quite easy to aim in VR compared to some other weapons, the Tokarev packs a decent punch and can take down human enemies with a single headshot.

Ammo for the Tokarev is abundant, and the standard-issue glow sights certainly help with its accuracy. The only downsides to this pistol are its lack of ammo capacity and power against more heavily armored enemies or strong mutants.

6 Helsing

A Highly Functional And Stealthy Crossbow

The Helsing is a unique gas-powered crossbow that holds up to six bolts and fires them silently at a fairly decent range. The Helsing is remarkably accurate considering its rather hamfisted and improvised appearance.

hile it is ideally suited for taking down human enemies, the Helsing will also be reasonably effective against smaller mutants like Nosalises. However, it is worth remembering that this weapon's longer reload times may become a factor when facing off against several of the creatures at once.

5 Grenade

An Improvised Explosive With Devastating Effects

Sometimes the best way to deal with a problem in the next room is to simply blow it up. The makeshift hand grenades (or pipe bombs may be a more accurate description) will generate a decent-sized blast and will most certainly flush groups of enemies out from behind cover, or stun larger mutants if not kill them altogether.

The grenade pin must be pulled and the fuse will gradually shorten, which makes it one of the most fun weapons to use in VR. Having a reasonable supply of grenades will provide a degree of tactical versatility. Just make sure those VR wrist straps are fully secure before throwing one!

4 Kalash

A Common But Powerful Assault Rifle

The Kalash is one of the most common weapons found throughout Metro Awakening , but it's also one of the better guns players will come across. With good damage, reasonable accuracy, and, most importantly, a decent magazine size, the Kalash makes for the ideal all-rounder for the majority of the game.

Where it falls short is in its stealth ability, which is virtually non-existent. However, the Kalash more than makes up for any deficits in this department with its solid fire rate. Overall, it is usually better to have one of these rifles than not, even if it's just used as a backup option.

3 DShK

A High-Caliber Mounted Machine Gun

The DShK is a mounted heavy machine gun that players will be able to use at various stages of the game. Though it cannot be moved, it has by far the strongest combination of damage output and fire rate in the game; thus, it is ideally suited for taking down stronger mutants.

Although players will only get to use this weapon in limited circumstances, it is such great fun to use and noticeably different from using the other weapons in the game. Just make sure to fire in bursts. Otherwise, the DShK is prone to overheating, which can be very costly.

2 Blowgun

An Improvised And Ancient Stealth Weapon

The Blowgun is a new weapon introduced in Metro Awakening and is predominantly used by cultist enemies. Being both silent and accurate, as well as highly powerful, it is suited to the game's stealth sections and will make a big difference when it comes to strategy.

Though ammunition may not be as readily available for the Blowgun, it's easy to see where the advantage of this weapon lies. The small circular sight makes a big difference in VR, enabling players to hit targets much more easily. However, they probably won't want to pull this out in the middle of an intense gunfight.

1 Shambler

A Highly-Powerful And Effective Revolver-Shotgun

When it comes to Metro Awakening , and indeed the Metro series in general, close-quarters-combat is expected and common. Therefore, it helps to have a powerful close-range weapon. What better option is there than the Shambler shotgun?

Firing a revolving cylinder of up to six shells, the Shambler is great for taking down both human and mutant enemies alike, but will be particularly effective against Nosalises. The Shambler also has some great interactive animations, which are great fun for long-time fans of the series.

item.title: Genshin Impact Pattern Suggests Natlan Will Feature Another Powerful Pyro Character Besides Mavuika
item.description:
Summary

  • Genshin Impact players speculate that the Natlan arc may introduce a new powerful Pyro character alongside Mavuika.
  • A Reddit user pointed out that every Archon has had a story-relevant character with the same element, suggesting the same could apply to Mavuika.
  • Fans hope the new Pyro character will synergize well with Mavuika, addressing concerns about her versatility in gameplay.

Genshin Impact players have noticed an interesting pattern suggesting that HoYoverse could add another powerful Pyro user during the Natlan arc. Genshin Impact 's most recent major update introduced the long-awaited Pyro nation, Natlan, along with several new playable units.

The most recently added characters are Chasca and Ororon, who arrived as part of the ongoing update 5.2. HoYoverse has already confirmed that the next update will introduce the long-awaited Pyro Archon, Mavuika, and the famous fortune-teller Citlali. Both are confirmed to arrive in the first banner cycle of the upcoming version 5.3.

While Mavuika is yet to join the roster officially, players have already started speculating about a new powerful character who could share the same element as the Natlan Archon. A Reddit user named the_dark_artist shared a chart showing that all the previously released Archons have been paired with another powerful character of the same element who is integral to the main storyline. For example, the first Archon to appear in the game was Genshin Impact 's Anemo user Venti, who was paired with Jean, the Acting Grandmaster of the Knights of Favonius, a character arguably just as important to the Mondstadt region, at least in the current timeline. Liyue's Ningguang is the only character on the list with a lower four-star rarity.

Genshin Impact Player Theory Hints at New Pyro Character

The post gained significant attention in the community, with many fans claiming that Natlan needs a Pyro character who would complement Mavuika both in terms of the story and gameplay. It would not be surprising if HoYoverse decides to introduce such a powerful character in the later stages of the Natlan arc, especially since recent Genshin Impact leaks revealed that Capitano won't be joining the roster, at least not for now.

Some of these "sidekick" characters have been rumored to be even more powerful than their Archon counterparts. One prime example is Fontaine's Neuvillette, who is also known as one of Genshin Impact 's Seven Sovereigns. Since Mavuika's kit reveal, players have been complaining about her abilities being more restrictive compared to previously released Archons, who are known for their versatility in fitting almost any team composition.

Some fans have suggested that this new character could have excellent synergy with Genshin Impact 's Natlan Archon in battle, potentially addressing some of these concerns. According to the comment section, Natlan's first Archon, also known as Xbalanque, would be the perfect character to fill this role.

item.title: Monster Hunter Fan Designs Pokemon Line for Pukei-Pukei
item.description:
Summary

  • A fan created a Pokemon evolution line for Monster Hunter's Pukei-Pukei, called the "Pukeimon line."
  • Pukei-Pukei from Monster Hunter is a fan-favorite creature known for its design and poison abilities.
  • It is currently unknown if Pukei-Pukei will appear in the upcoming Monster Hunter Wilds.

A Monster Hunter fan has created a Pokemon evolution line for the popular monster Pukei-Pukei from the Capcom franchise. Pukei-Pukei has been featured in recent Monster Hunter titles, but its presence in the series' next mainline game is still uncertain.

Pukei-Pukei are a kind of bird wyvern that was first introduced in Monster Hunter World . An alternate breed called Coral Pukei-Pukei also debuted in the game's Iceborn DLC. The Pukei-Pukei's interesting design and poison-spitting abilities turned it into a fan-favorite monster from recent games. Pukei-Pukei are among Monster Hunter World 's most dangerous monsters in certain areas, and it is also a worthy opponent in later titles like Monster Hunter Rise and Monster Hunter Now . Like many Monster Hunter creatures, the Pukei-Pukei is inspired by real-life animals like reptiles and birds. In a similar manner, the Pokemon franchise is known for having real-life-based monsters. One Monster Hunter fan saw the potential of crossing both video game series and created a Pokemon version of the Pukei-Pukei​​​​​​.

Reddit user Onlyhasart designed a Pokemon evolution line for the Pukei-Pukei from the Monster Hunter series. The artist dubbed it the "Pukeimon line" and gave the Pukei-Pukei two pre-forms. The first is an adorable small creature named Lafi-Lafi, which evolves into Toki-Toki and finally into Pukei-Pukei. Onlyhasart imagined how Pukei-Pukei would be illustrated in the Pokemon art style and accurately captured its features. Pokemon has influenced Monster Hunter in the past, so connecting both franchises in fan art is quite a logical notion. Under the fan art post, fans praised the artist's creativity and talent, with one fan suggesting that Pukei-Pukei could be a Flying-Poison-type Pokemon.

Monster Hunter Fan Designs Pokemon Evolutions for Pukei-Pukei

While Pukei-Pukei have appeared consistently in the series' latest titles, it hasn't been confirmed whether it will be in Monster Hunter Wilds ' creature lineup. There are rumors that some Monster Hunter World creatures like the Ebony Odogaron will be returning, so a Pukei-Pukei comeback is still a possibility. However, fans will have to wait for an official announcement from Capcom for confirmation.

Anticipation for the next Monster Hunter mainline game has risen after a very successful open beta in late October. Capcom has revealed several features coming to Monster Hunter Wilds , such as PS5 Pro enhancements and performance customizations. There are high expectations for Monster Hunter Wilds , as it is easily one of the most anticipated releases in 2025.

item.title: Every PlayStation Console's Release Date And Launch Price
item.description:
Quick Links

  • PlayStation
  • PS One
  • PlayStation 2
  • PlayStation 2 Slimeline
  • PlayStation 3
  • PlayStation 3 Slim
  • PlayStation 3 Super Slim
  • PlayStation 4
  • PlayStation 4 Slim
  • PlayStation 4 Pro
  • PlayStation 5
  • PlayStation 5 Digital
  • PlayStation 5 Slim
  • PlayStation 5 Slim Digital
  • PlayStation 5 Pro
  • PlayStation Portable
  • PSP GO
  • PSP Street
  • PlayStation Vita
  • PlayStation TV

Over roughly three decades, Sony has firmly established the PlayStation brand as a staple of the gaming landscape. Ever since the PS1 was announced and fairly quickly garnered a foothold in the industry, the manufacturer has been producing (mostly) successful consoles that aim to balance accessibility, evolution, and power. As can be seen with the PS5 Pro, Sony revealing a PlayStation console will always inspire discussions, be it positive or negative.

While the discourse currently revolves around Sony's future, this is also the perfect time to look at the company's past, specifically concerning the release dates and launch prices. The PS5 Pro is something of an outlier, but Sony is not above throwing the occasional curveball when it comes to console reveals.

Updated on December 28, 2024 by Mark Sammut: Now that the PS5 Pro has been out for a couple of months, this is a good opportunity to expand on the section dedicated to that console.

Only the main PlayStation console models will be included, and no peripherals like PS VR or PlayStation Portable. Also, the focus is on North America, and the prices have not been adjusted for inflation.

PlayStation

September 9, 1995

  • Japanese Release Date: December 3, 1994
  • Launch Price (NA): $299
  • Discontinued (NA): March 23, 2006

Sony's console debut, the original PlayStation, is still arguably the company's most iconic system, even if it was not quite as successful as some of its successors. Compared to pretty much every other PlayStation home console, the PS1 had a fairly short run as Sony's main platform; however, it put PlayStation on the map and instantly established the brand as a direct competitor and alternative to Nintendo and Sega.

PS One

September 19, 2000

  • Japanese Release Date: July 7, 2000
  • Launch Price (NA): $99
  • Discontinued (NA): March 23, 2006

Released very late in the PS1's lifespan and after the PS2's debut in Japan, the PS One was a budget option that was also designed around portability, at least to an extent. If they wanted to, players had the option to buy an LCD screen that could be attached to the system. While not among the most decorated or fondly remembered PlayStation consoles, the PS One did foreshadow Slim systems that would eventually become the norm.

PlayStation 2

October 26, 2000

  • Japanese Release Date: March 4, 2000
  • Launch Price (NA): $299
  • Discontinued (NA): January 4, 2013

Building swiftly on the success of the PS1, the PlayStation 2 was unquestionably the leading console of its generation, and an argument could be made that it still represents Sony's peak in gaming. Along with offering a significant boost in power compared to its predecessor, the PS2 could also double as a DVD player, giving it an edge over the Nintendo GameCube. With a massive library filled with all-time masterpieces, this console was and still is great.

PlayStation 2 Slimeline

November 3, 2004

  • European Release Date: October 29, 2004
  • Launch Price (NA): $149
  • Discontinued (NA): January 4, 2013

Officially starting Sony's run with mid-generation alternative consoles, the PS2 Slimline was considerably cheaper and even managed to include a few upgrades like an Ethernet port. That said, the Slim version had its share of issues that impacted compatibility with games and just general reliability. While still a decent option at the time, the original PS2 is the superior overall console and the one to pick up if someone is looking to add to their retro collection.

PlayStation 3

November 17, 2006

  • Japanese Release Date: November 11, 2006
  • Storage Sizes: 20/40/60/80/160 GB
  • Launch Price (NA): $499 (20 GB)/$599 (60 GB)
  • Discontinued (NA): October 2016 (Specific Date Not Available)

After two generations of (mostly) home runs, Sony arguably had its first major stumble with the reveal of the PS3. Considerably more expensive than the norm and boasting a relatively weak line-up of launch titles, the PlayStation 3 had a rough start that arguably persisted for years, with the console only really picking up steam after 2010. This generation also utilized a unique internal architecture that complicated the process of developing games for it, and all these years later, PS3 titles still have to be streamed rather than downloaded on PS Plus. That said, the PS3 did eventually turn things around.

PlayStation 3 Slim

September 1, 2009

  • Japanese Release Date: August 27, 2009
  • Storage Sizes: 120/160/250/320 GB
  • Launch Price (NA): $299 (120 GB)
  • Discontinued: October 2016 (Specific Date Not Available)

Arguably, the PS3's fortunes began to change with the arrival of the Slim variant, which came with a fair more attractive price, along with a more appealing and lightweight design. While not all the changes were positive (this marked the point when Sony temporarily dropped backward compatibility), the PlayStation 3 Slim was nevertheless a substantial upgrade over its maligned predecessor, and it was among the best overall media options at the time.

PlayStation 3 Super Slim

September 25, 2012

  • Storage Sizes: 12/250/500 GB
  • Launch Price (NA): $269 (250 GB)
  • Discontinued: October 2016 (Specific Date Not Available)

A move that Sony has yet to repeat, the PS3 received another Slim iteration, with the Super Slim coming out roughly a year before the PS4's debut. Although the disc loader is generally quite polarizing, the Super Slim was nevertheless a solid expansion of its predecessor's strengths. The original version came with 250 GB of storage, but a 12 GB iteration was also available for those who just used discs or wanted to add an HDD.

PlayStation 4

November 15, 2013

  • Storage Sizes : 500 GB
  • Launch Price (NA): $349
  • Discontinued (NA): Not Yet

After the turbulent PS3 era, Sony did not take any risks with the PlayStation 4, launching the console at an immediately competitive price while providing a traditional architecture that could allow third-party developers to port projects without too many issues. The PS4 was a smash hit right out of the gate, instantly dominating the generation ahead of the Xbox One. Even more than a decade after its debut, the console is still available and regularly receives new games.

PlayStation 4 Slim

September 15, 2016

  • Storage Sizes : 500 GB Or 1 TB
  • Launch Price (NA): $299 (500 GB)/$349 (1 TB)
  • Discontinued (NA): Not Yet

Very much delivering what its name advertises, the PS4 Slim is, ultimately, just a smaller version of the base console. Beyond that, this model comes with a few updates to coincide with advances in things like USBs and Bluetooth. Honestly, the biggest changes happened in April 2017 when the 1 TB PS4 Slim became the norm, offering a substantial boost in space for a still decent price.

PlayStation 4 Pro

November 10, 2016

  • Storage Sizes: 1 TB
  • Launch Price (NA): $399
  • Discontinued (NA): Not Yet

Somewhat overshadowing the Slim iteration, the PS4 Pro was Sony's first attempt to provide a notable mid-generation upgrade, something that has now been repeated with the PS5. While not a game-changing leap, the Pro iteration offered an improved CPU and GPU that could support some 4K output, along with just being able to better run PS VR games. Honestly, the latter was probably one of the biggest reasons that the PS4 Pro became a reality.

PlayStation 5

November 12, 2020

  • Storage Sizes: 825 GB
  • Launch Price (NA): $499.99
  • Discontinued (NA): October/November 2023

Entering this generation as the unquestionable leader (as Nintendo exists in a separate ecosystem), Sony launched the PlayStation 5 from a position of strength, which was reflected in the hardware's launch MSRB. Still, the PS5 was a powerful system for 2020, offering limited 4K and 60fps support. The console also came with the DualSense, arguably Sony's best controller. Towards the end of 2023, the original PS5 was discontinued in favor of the Slim model.

PlayStation 5 Digital

November 12, 2020

  • Storage Sizes: 825 GB
  • Launch Price (NA): $399.99
  • Discontinued (NA): October/November 2023

In a move that reflected the market's gradual shift towards digital purchases, Sony opted to provide a PS5 Digital for anyone who had no intention of picking up discs. In 2020, this prospect did not seem that appetizing as PS Now had a fairly negative reputation; however, Sony eventually revamped the subscription service as PS Plus, which is in a good state nowadays. Nevertheless, the original Digital Edition was a commitment as a disc drive could not be bought separately if somebody decided they would rather have that functionality. Similar to the standard PS5, this console was discontinued in 2023 in favor of the Slim Digital Edition.

PlayStation 5 Slim

November 10, 2023

  • Storage Sizes: 1 TB
  • Launch Price (NA): $499
  • Discontinued (NA): Current Main Console

The PS5 Slim very much lives up to its popular name: this is the PS5 but smaller. That might sound like an insignificant change, but the vanilla version is notoriously huge, so the Slim is certainly easier to manage. Beyond that, it has a slightly bigger SSD and more ports.

PlayStation 5 Slim Digital

November 10, 2023

  • Storage Sizes: 1 TB
  • Launch Price (NA): $449.99
  • Discontinued (NA): Current Main Console

Similar to the standard iteration, the PS5 Slim Digital Edition is mostly the same as its predecessor, albeit with a smaller overall size. That said, a disc drive can be attached to this version, meaning players are not married to digital gaming if they opt to go with this edition.

PlayStation 5 Pro

November 7, 2024

  • Storage Sizes: 2 TB
  • Launch Price (NA): $699
  • Discontinued (NA): Current Console

With the PlayStation 4 setting the precedent for mid-generation Pro upgrades, the PlayStation 5 following in the same footsteps seemed to be a given. Technically, that did happen, with Sony announcing a PS5 Pro in September 2024, along with a release date for a few months later. So far, so normal; however, this system ended up being quite a departure from the PS4 Pro, in more ways than one. Firstly, the console's price tag is considerably higher, making it very much a niche piece rather than a must-own upgrade that most PS5 owners will want to at least consider. A disc drive is not included either. Also, the Pro's release did not coincide with a price decrease for the "standard" PS5 (or the Slim), something that happened during the PS4 era.

In terms of spec improvements, the PS5 Pro is the most powerful console on the market, which makes sense considering it is far more expensive than the competition. Going through the console's tech, the two biggest changes are the GPU and the SSD, both of which received fairly substantial upgrades. The former ties directly into the PS5 Pro's Ray-Tracing capabilities, along with the introduction of PSSR (an AI upscaling software that is pretty impressive). Quite a few games take advantage of the PS5 PRO's heightened power to present their definitive versions on consoles. The PS5 Pro might not be a must-own system by any means, but it is an impressive piece of tech in its own right.

PlayStation Portable

March 24, 2005

  • Japanese Release Date: December 11, 2004
  • Launch Price (NA): $249.99
  • Discontinued (NA): 2014

The PlayStation Portable marked Sony's first foray into handheld gaming, and the console was generally a massive success that initially seemed capable of challenging Nintendo's dominance in the field. While that did not ultimately happen, the console's 3D capabilities, expansive library, and popularity in Japan ensured a respectable legacy.

The PSP received three models: PSP-1000, PSP-2000, and PSP-3000.

PSP GO

October 1, 2009

  • Storage Sizes: 16 GB
  • Launch Price (NA): $249.99
  • Discontinued (2011): April 20, 2011

In many ways, the PSP GO was ahead of its time. A digital-only console was rather surprising in 2009, even if the PS Store had been around for a while by that point. The system came with 16 GB of memory at launch, which was mostly OK for PSP games. Unfortunately, this iteration did not perform that well and had a short shelf life.

PSP Street

October 26, 2011

  • Launch Price (EU): €99
  • Discontinued (EU): 2014

Perhaps the most obscure PlayStation console , the PSP Street did not receive a North American release. Very much intended to be the most budget option imaginable, this model could not support Wi-Fi and was seemingly designed to be the direct opposite of the PSP Go.

PlayStation Vita

February 15, 2012

  • Japanese Release Date: December 17, 2011
  • Launch Price (NA): $249.99
  • Discontinued (NA): March 1, 2019

Considering the success of the PSP, the PlayStation Vita seemed poised to be a hit, especially since it was far and away the most powerful handheld system on the market. The inclusion of two joysticks was also a big improvement over the PSP, and the console was generally all-around great. Unfortunately, the PS Vita never quite maximized its potential and seemed to become an afterthought fairly quickly, eventually to the point of barely receiving any exclusives.

Similar to the original PSP, the Vita received a revised model a few years into its lifespan, with the PCH-2000 iteration being more lightweight and even containing 1 GB of storage.

PlayStation TV

October 14, 2014

  • Japanese Release Date: November 14, 2013
  • Storage Sizes: 1 GB
  • Launch Price (NA): $99
  • Discontinued (NA): 2015

Although not making a huge splash, the PS TV was a fairly impressive piece of tech that, unfortunately, struggled to find an audience outside of Japan. The system was designed to play a select range of PS Vita games on a TV, which was a pretty great idea. Ultimately, there did not seem to be that much demand for this type of release, although an argument could be made that the PS Vita and PS TV somewhat foreshadowed the Nintendo Switch's hybrid concept.

item.title: Supermarket Together: How to Manage Employees
item.description:
Quick Links

  • How to Hire Employees in Supermarket Together
  • How to Assign Employees in Supermarket Together
  • How to Manage Employee Happiness in Supermarket Together

Supermarket Together is a grocery store simulator game where you start from scratch and get a chance to build your superstore from the ground up. From stocking your shelves with products, setting up pricing, and even hiring staff, the game gives you plenty of tools to play however you see fit.

While the game starts off easy, with limited products to manage and a handful of customers to care for, things pick up pace as soon as you get through the initial few days. Things get easier when you've got friends helping you out, but hiring and managing employees effectively is the key to success for solo players. In this guide, we'll tell you all you need to know about hiring employees and managing them properly in Supermarket Together .

How to Hire Employees in Supermarket Together

To hire an employee in Supermarket Together , you'll first have to unlock an Employee perk from the Franchise Board using Franchise Points. It's this game's version of experience points, and you earn them daily while checking out customers. The game also shows you how many Franchise Points you earned in the end-of-day report when you close up shop, depending on your profits. There are a total of 12 Employee perks that you can acquire by spending Franchise Points.

Each Employee perk allows you to hire an additional employee.

Once you've acquired an Employee perk, head to the Manager Blackboard in the Manager's Room and switch to the Employees tab. To hire an employee, click on the Hire button. You'll now see a list of employees available for hire, their overall rating, and their daily wages.

You can click the reroll button to get a fresh batch of candidates.

Clicking on each employee brings up the Employee's Stats window, which breaks down their expertise in individual sectors. You can also assign a name to your employee by filling in the text box under the stats. Once you find an employee you want, click the Hire button to add them to your payroll.

To fire an employee, switch to the Dismiss tab, click on the employee you want to let go of, and select Dismiss.

How to Assign Employees in Supermarket Together

After hiring an employee, they will go to the Staff Room outside the store near the exit from the Manager's Room. They will stay there until you assign them a task. To assign a task to your employee, head back to the Manager Blackboard and click on the Assignment button in the Employees tab.

All your hired employees will show up in this tab. Click the No Task button below their stats and choose what you want them to do. Currently, you can assign your employees to do the following tasks in Supermarket Together :

  • No Task: The employee will do nothing and just wait in the Staff Room.
  • Cashier: The employee will man an empty cash register and collect payments from the customers
  • Restocker: The employee will restock empty product shelves with products from the Storage Shelves.
  • Storage: The employee will fill up the Storage Shelves with new products after you place a Product Order.
  • Security: The employee will pick up a Broom and stand guard at the store's entrance to deal with shoplifters and thieves.

How to Manage Employee Happiness in Supermarket Together

At the moment, the happiness of your employees doesn't matter too much in Supermarket Together . As long as they have the right stats for it, they will continue working on your assigned task. However, to ensure your staff members are as happy as they can be, you'll have to spend money towards developing the Staff Room.

Assigning them to tasks that are suited to their skills also improves employee happiness.

Developing the Staff Room can be done by heading to the location and switching to the Staff Room tab in the Build menu. Add a few pieces of furniture and watch the happiness of your employees go up. Small, cheap items like a Basic Table or Chair can raise Employee Happiness by 0.1, while bigger investments such as a Dart Board or Pool Table can have a bigger impact on Staffroom Happiness.

The Employee tab on the Manager Blackboard shows the total Staffroom Happiness.

Finding success in Supermarket Together requires careful planning and management. The number of customers that come flooding in, especially in higher-difficulty settings, can be managed a lot easier when you've got a few employees helping out around the store.
